cancel.title: Cancel Upgrade
cancel.description: If upgrade is canceled, nodes will return to "ready" state and you will be redirected to the dashboard. If any changes were already made to the cloud (e.g. new repositories were configured), they will not be reverted automatically. You will need to manually revert those changes to fully return the cloud to the previous state.
cancel.question: Are you sure you want to cancel the upgrade process?

prechecks.title: Preliminary Checks
prechecks.description: Run the checks below to determine if your cloud is prepared for upgrade.

upgrade.title: Begin Upgrade
upgrade.description: Click on "Begin Upgrade" below to start the upgrade process.

mode.title: Upgrade Mode
mode.description: After all mandatory checks are successful the upgrade mode of your cloud will be shown here...

normal.title: Your cloud is now prepared to begin the upgrade process in normal mode.
normal.description1: In normal mode, you will need to shutdown or suspend all of the workloads running on each node. You can start or resume them again once the upgrade is finished. You will be notified once such action is necessary.
normal.description2: In order to proceed in non-disruptive mode your cloud needs to be configured as Highly Available and have enough free compute resources. See the deployment guide for details.
normal.description3: Be sure to re-run the checks if you make any changes to your cloud after the initial run.

nondisruptive.title: Your cloud is now prepared to begin the upgrade process in non-disruptive mode.
nondisruptive.description1: In non-disruptive mode all workloads should continue running and be accessible from the outside.
nondisruptive.description2: Be sure to re-run the checks if you make any changes to your cloud after the initial run.

backup.title: Create a backup of the Administration Server configuration and download it in your browser
backup.description: This backup contains information about the cloud deployment and configuration. Keep this backup somewhere safe in case of emergency.
backup.location: Backup can be found under "{{path}}" on Administration Server.

admin-repository-checks.title: Upgrading to SUSE OpenStack Cloud 9 requires updated software repositories for the Administration Server
admin-repository-checks.description: Prepare the software repositories locally or via SMT and update the URLs in the Administration Server configuration correspondingly. Refer to "Software Repository Setup" chapter of the deployment guide. Click "Check" to verify all repositories are available. When all repositories have been verified click on "Next" to proceed.

upgrade-admin.title: Upgrade the Administration Server to SUSE OpenStack Cloud 9
upgrade-admin.description: Please wait until the Administration Server has been upgraded and rebooted.
upgrade-admin.notice-body: This process might take quite some time. Please do not close the browser window or refresh the page.

nodes-repository-checks.title: Upgrading to SUSE OpenStack Cloud 9 requires updated software repositories for all nodes
nodes-repository-checks.description: Prepare the software repositories locally or via SMT and update the URLs in the Administration Server configuration correspondingly. Refer to "Software Repository Setup" chapter of the deployment guide. Click "Check" to verify all repositories are available. When all repositories have been verified click on "Next" to proceed.

openstack-services.title: Stop OpenStack services
openstack-services.description: It is imperative that during and after stopping the OpenStack services no changes are made to your cloud. After this step, OpenStack APIs will not be available until the upgrade process is finished.
openstack-services.normal-mode-note: Before executing Stop Services action, make sure no workloads are running on any of your compute nodes. You need to shutdown or susspend all of them now. You can start or resume them again once the upgrade is finished.

openstack-backup.title: Back up the OpenStack database
openstack-backup.description: Backup of OpenStack database will be downloaded from one of database nodes and stored on the Administration Server. Depending on the size of your database this process might take quite some time. Once created, the backup can be found in /var/lib/crowbar/backup on Administration Server.
openstack-backup.location: Backup can be found under "{{path}}" on Administration Server.

upgrade-nodes.title: Begin upgrading and migrating nodes by clicking on the button below
upgrade-nodes.description: This process might take some time depending upon the size of your cloud and workloads. Uncheck the 'Upgrade Compute Nodes' box if you wish to only upgrade the controller nodes and postpone the upgrade of compute nodes. You can start the upgrade process of the compute nodes again after the controller node upgrade has been completed.
upgrade-nodes.finished: Upgrade is completed. Click the Finish button to go back to the dashboard.
upgrade-nodes.partially-upgraded: Upgrade of the controller nodes has been completed. Press the 'Upgrade Nodes' button to upgrade the compute nodes now. Otherwise, uncheck the 'Upgrade Compute Nodes' box and press the 'Go to Dashboard' button if you wish to upgrade the compute nodes at a later time.

codes.SLES12-SP3-Updates: SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12 SP3 Updates
codes.SLE12-SP3-HA-Pool: SUSE Linux Enterprise 12 SP3 High Availability
codes.SLE12-SP3-HA-Updates: SUSE Linux Enterprise 12 SP3 High Availability Updates
codes.SLES12-SP4-Updates: SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12 SP4 Updates
codes.SLE12-SP4-HA-Pool: SUSE Linux Enterprise 12 SP4 High Availability
codes.SLE12-SP4-HA-Updates: SUSE Linux Enterprise 12 SP4 High Availability Updates

errors.ha_configured: Cloud is not configured as Highly Available
errors.ha_not_installed: High Availability module is not present
errors.clusters_health_failed_actions: Some Clusters Health actions have failed

footer.text: SUSE OpenStack Cloud - provided by SUSE
